 ARGENTINA STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT FORESTRY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT I. PLANTATIONS, TIMBER PROCESSING AND AGROFORESTRY A. Background 1.1 Argentina's forest plantations have clear natural advantages compared with those in many countries. These advantages stem mainly from: (a) the fast growth rates of trees in Argentina resulting from relatively rich soils and favorable temperatures and rainfall; and (b) an abundance of land with few alternative uses. In spite of these advantages, forest plantations in earlier decades were not developed in line with the potential, principally because of unfavorable macroeconomic, trade, and other policies. In recent years many of these policies have been adjusted appropriately, and the improved economic and policy environment now encourages investments. 1.2 The forest resources of Argentina are made up of both native forests and plantations. Land with woody vegetation is estimated at about 64 million ha (23 percent of the total area of the country), of which forested land is estimated at between 35 and 45 million ha. The area of native forest with commercial potential is estimated at about 15 million ha; it produces about 7.3 million m3 of wood per annum, equal to about 40 percent of the country's annual production. The remainder comes from plantations, whose area is estimated at about 900,000 ha. 1.3 The forestry sector in Argentina contributes just under 2 percent of GDP and had a positive trade balance of US$132.1 million in 1989. While it now contributes positively to the trade balance, this was achieved only by 1988. The contrast between the performance of the forestry sectors in Argentina and Chile could hardly be more striking. While Argentina is about 3.7 times the size of Chile in area, and about 3 times its size in terms of GDP, Chile's exports of forest products, at about US$1.0 billion annually, are almost 4 times greater than Argentina's. 1.4 From 1980 to 1989, the area under plantations in Argentina grew only 7.5 percent. From 1970 to 1990, Argentina planted about 1 million ha of forests; over the same period, Brazil planted about 6 million ha, and between 1978 and 1990, Chile planted 1.3 million ha. Chile developed an export-oriented industry which enabled it to develop well beyond the requirements of the domestic economy. Brazil suffered from macroeconomic and policy distortions similar to those of Argentina, but the size of the domestic market was much larger, enabling its forestry sector to expand rapidly. Argentina was constrained both by macroeconomic and
 - 2 - sector policy distortions and by the small size of its domestic market. In comparing Argentina with Chile, in particular, it becomes clear that a substantial gap exists in Argentina between the actual and potential levels of forest plantation production. Furthermore, much of the past growth in forest plantations in Argentina has not been efficient. B. Priorities for Government Action 1.5 The challenge facing the Argentine government in dealing with forest plantations, timber processing and agroforestry is how to narrow the gap that now exists between the actual and the potential sustainable levels of efficient output. Defining an appropriate role for the state is critical in the development and consideration of government options. 1.6 Commercial forestry may be defined as the planting, harvesting, transport, processing, and marketing of trees and/or forest products. There are two specific aspects of commercial forestry, so defined, that justify a role for the state different from that in other commercial activities. 1.7 Investments in forest plantations generate joint products: a commercial product, timber, and a non-commercial product, carbon sequestration, which is a global externality. While this is not a sufficient reason for Argentina to support a forest plantation payment scheme using domestic resources, it is a reason why such plantations should be considered for support in carefully selected circumstances by any international fund established to lower carbon levels in the atmosphere. A Carbon Sequestration Project, which would focus on sequestering carbon in forest plantations, native forests and scrubs, is under preparation, and the Government has approached the Global Environment Facility (GEF) for its support. 1.8 Native forests produce commercial products such as timber, charcoal, and nuts, but they also produce a range of non-commercial goods and services. Examples are: serving as sinks for carbon sequestration, a global externality; preventing soil erosion, buffering water flows, and protecting biodiversity and watersheds, which generate global, regional, and/or national externalities. The production of public goods by native forests requires that they be treated in special ways by the state and society at large, and this requires an appropriate incentive framework of laws and regulations. The government of Argentina decided in 1991 to assign public sector responsibility for green environmental issues and all aspects of native forests to a newly created Secretariat of Natural Resources and Human Environment (SRNyAH) within the Presidency of the Republic. A separate project (Native Forests and Protected Areas), which would be managed by SRNyAH and which would address the above issues, is under preparation, and the Government has approached the Bank for its support. In addition, a complementary Biodiversity Protection Project, which would focus on
 - 3 - protecting biodiversity of global significance and importance, is also under preparation and the Government has approached the Global Environment Facility (GEF) for its support. 1.9 Given that the two exceptions just noted are being handled separately, the challenge remaining for the Government is to realize the efficient growth potential of forest plantations, timber processing industries, and agroforestry while avoiding the negative externalities associated with the loss of native forests to logging and conversion to other uses. This requires that the future source of growth in the output of commercial forestry products shifts progressively toward plantations and away from native forests. In turn, this requires a rapid increase in both the productivity and output of plantations, but this growth should be efficient and, therefore, quite different from much that occurred in the past. It should be driven by improved access to better quality information and incentives which reflect the full range of costs and benefits, both private and public. 1.10 The most important policies for the promotion and development of forest plantations, timber processing industries, and agroforestry are those that affect the economy as a whole. These may be grouped into several broad categories: (a) macroeconomic and trade policies; (b) capital markets; (c) transportation and ports; and (d) labor markets. Public sector policies affecting forest plantations, timber processing industries, and agroforestry specifically are also important and may be grouped into two broad categories, forestry sector laws and regulations, and research, standards, and information. Economy-Wide Policies 1.11 Macroeconomic and Trade Policies. Argentina's poor performance in forest plantations, timber processing industries, and agroforestry results in large part from the strategy of import substitution adopted after World War II. This strategy, which was economy-wide and was implemented through implicit taxation of agriculture and rural areas, and protection of industry and urban areas, benefitted in particular the pulp and paper industry within the forest sector. The pulp and paper industry is capital intensive with large economies of scale, and tends to be concentrated in a small number of large firms. This concentration facilitates lobbying activities. In addition to the economy-wide policies which supported industrial development in general, virtually every forest sector policy and regulation adopted was for the benefit of the pulp and paper group. The most important of these policies were tariffs on the import of pulp and paper products, export taxes on logs, grants for tree planting, and regulations requiring replanting when trees have been cut. The implicit result of the various instruments was a tax on privately owned native forest and a subsidy to forest plantations. The efficiency implications were: (a) an industry incapable of facing export markets competitively; (b) the crowding-out of non-pulp and paper industries competing for the same resource base, such as
 - 4 - mechanical wood products; (c) land use misallocations towards specific types of plantations; and (d) environmental losses due to natural forest conversion to plantations. Public expenditure programs were similarly biased. 1.12 Continued liberalization of the economy is necessary to create a business climate conducive to the long-term investments required in plantations and timber processing industries if Argentina is to start realizing its potential in these areas. The reform program adopted by the Argentine government since 1989 is putting these conditions in place. For example, the level of inflation is now down to under five percent per annum, an extraordinary achievement considering the four-digit levels common in the 1980s. One direct effect of this is to lower the risk in long-term investments such as forest plantations. 1.13 Continued trade liberalization is necessary because forest plantations and timber processing industries will depend on export markets for the sale of much of their new production, and access to capital goods and other inputs priced at world levels is essential for competitiveness. Fortunately, the trade regime has been liberalized and made more neutral even if some further refining is still needed, particularly from the perspective of plantations. Remaining trade distortions are due mainly to the costs of port regulations, which in 1992 were estimated to be still 4.9 percent of border prices. 1.14 Capital Markets. Long-term investments such as those in forest plantations are critically dependent on the development and efficient functioning of Argentine capital markets. At least in the medium to long term, forest plantations must look to the capital markets for the solution to their financing needs. Therefore, any action the government takes to foster the development of efficient capital markets (including the lowering of inflation expectations, which, in turn, will lead to lower real interest rates) will directly benefit the forestry sector, particularly the processing stages in the short term, but ultimately the earlier plantation phase as well. 1.15 Equity financing is being welcomed by the government, and there is today considerable interest from foreign firms, particularly Chilean, in investing in the Argentine forest sector. 1.16 Transport and Port Sectors. High transport costs have also been among the critical factors hampering the development of forest plantations and timber processing industries; forest products have low value to volume or weight ratios, making transport costs a large share of total production and marketing costs (transport costs can amount to 50 percent of the FOB cost of unprocessed timber products). Furthermore, before the recent reforms, the average cost of handling wood in an Argentinean port was about three times the average international figure. Continuing and further deepening the reform process throughout the transport and port sectors are vital to forest plantation and timber processing development.
 - 5 - Great progress has been made to date in deregulating transport and ports and in transferring activities to the private sector. The critical reform remaining is the further deregulation of road transport at the provincial level. 1.17 Labor Laws. Labor market imperfections have been very damaging, particularly for forest processing, but less so at the primary production level, at least directly. The critical issues in labor markets are the following: (a) workmen's compensation; (b) collective bargaining; (c) nature of labor contracts; and (d) labor taxes and contributions. Reform of labor laws and regulations has lagged reforms in other areas and must be further deepened if development of the forest sector is not to be stymied. The agenda of deregulation in place contains several projected reforms that are very relevant to commercial forestry, particularly the reform of workmen's compensation. Sector SpeciFic Policies 1.18 Laws and Regulations. Apart from maintaining and deepening the economy-wide policy reforms, the priority for forest plantations and timber processing industries is a review and reform of the legal and regulatory framework, both at the federal and provincial levels. Many regulations impose costs on forest plantations and timber processing operators yet achieve little in the way of public goals; they may even be perverse as, for example, when they create incentives to destroy native forests. These regulations should be identified, subjected to close scrutiny and, when they cannot be justified, changed. Identifying these will require a substantial amount of effort since nearly all forests (apart from national parks) are under provincial jurisdiction. The federal government will have to use persuasion and incentives to bring about the desired changes. 1.19 Research and Information Generation and Dissemination. Forest entrepreneurs and experts are unanimous in pointing to the absence of a forestry culture as a serious problem affecting forest plantations and timber processing. From an economic point of view, this argument reflects the high cost of information. Primary production in Argentina was directed almost exclusively at cereals and livestock, while other sectors were crowded out in terms of availability of information and statistics from public and private sources regarding the stock of plantation forests, grading standards, product development, and market opportunities. 1.20 A government investment role in the following areas related to forest plantations, timber processing industries, and agroforestry is justified by the public good content of these services: (a) inventory of forest plantations. and development and management of a commercial forestry database: completing an inventory of forest plantations, but only to the degree of detail required for purposes of public policy; inputting the data
 - 6 - generated and other statistics (e.g., prices and production statistics) into a database; analyzing and disseminating information from the database to the Argentine public and private sectors and to potential foreign investors; (b) forest plantation and timber processing research and information generation and dissemination: (i) marketing study: while there are export marketing associations in Argentina for mechanical-wood products, small and medium-size producers with no direct links to foreign markets have little knowledge of export market conditions and requirements (i.e., size and quality classes). Furthermore, due to the dispersion and small scale of the mechanical-wood- products' industry, it is unlikely that such associations will be able to substantially change the situation in the near future due to the high transaction costs involved. There is, therefore, a role for the government in helping mechanical-wood processing industries perform a range of activities, which private marketing associations may sometimes perform successfully, such as adopting wood grading systems, completing market analyses, and transport feasibility studies to help the industry focus its investments and take advantage of appropriate niches in foreign markets. Another argument favoring a governmental role in grading is that even when marketing associations exist, grading systems they may operate are of limited effectiveness since they often lack consumer confidence. The pulp and paper industries do not need such assistance; (ii) improving yenetic material and seedling quality: in forest plantations, improving the genetic quality of seedlings has elements of a public good due to a market failure: the inability to distinguish improved genotypes from poor genotypes in the visible characteristics of a plant until late in its lifecycle, which could be 20 years. Therefore, in principle, a direct government role in the improvement and certification of genetic quality, and the certification of improved quality seedlings, is appropriate; and (iii) plantation management: a government role in researching and disseminating technical information on improved plantation management techniques is justified because of a market failure: the inability of private parties to capture a sufficient share of the benefits to
 - 7 - justify the expenditures, and the high transactions costs should producer associations attempt to manage and finance such an activity. 1.21 The cold, arid Patagonia region occupies most of the southern part of Argentina. The region, which covers a total of 762,000 km2 (27 percent of the country's area), consists of three natural zones: (i) the Steppe, or arid grassland, which is the largest (650,000 km2) and most arid (750 to less than 300 mm precipitation/year); (ii) the Pre-Cordillera, which covers a narrow band of steeply sloping land of altitudes of around 1,000-2,000 meters above sea level (MASL), and with annual precipitation of around 750 to 2,000 mm; and (iii) the Cordillera, in the high Andes, with elevations above 2,000 MASL and annual precipitation of 1,000 to 3,000 mm. Strong winds are a characteristic of the entire region. While much of the Cordillera and Pre-Cordillera is well protected in the National Park's system, there are severe desertification problems in the Steppe zone. There is a lack of consensus concerning the underlying forces which are driving this phenomenon and the definition of an appropriate state role in responding to it. A comprehensive study of desertification in Patagonia is included in this project because: (a) of the interest shown by the government, specifically the Ministry of Economy; (b) the expectation that forestry will contribute to slowing the rate of desertification in that region; and (c) the past involvement and experience of the National Institute for Agricultural Research (INTA), which is part of SAGyP, in efforts to address the problem. 1.22 Outside the Pampa, small farmers comprise more than 40 percent of properties. Regionally, the highest concentration of small farmers is found in the Northeast and the Northwest where they are responsible for 40 percent and 20 percent, respectively, of the cropped area. According to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) (1993), these two regions contain 53 percent (i.e., 245,000 homes) of the rural poor in Argentina. The government is keen to use every efficient means and opportunity available to help alleviate rural poverty. Agroforestry offers an effective way, in certain circumstances, to help alleviate rural poverty and, for that reason, a small farmer component is included in the proposed project. C. Major Public Sector Institutions Involved 1.23 The role of the state in plantations, timber processing and agroforestry in Argentina includes: (a) adapting existing legislation and regulations to new requirements; (b) generating and disseminating appropriate information and data; (c) generating appropriate technology and making it available to the private sector directly or through extension activities; and (d) fostering forest-related training at all levels, including universities. 1.24 To perform this role adequately, substantial improvement is needed in institutional capacity. Until it was dismantled in late 1991, the
 - 8 - Argentine National Forestry Institute (IFONA), an autonomous institute under the institutional umbrella of SAGyP. was responsible for overall management of the forest sector2. IFONA's functions were divided between the SAGyP's Directorate for Forestry Production (DPF), which was given responsibility for forest plantations, timber processing industries and agroforestry, and the newly-created SRNyAH, which was given responsibility for native forests, protected areas, and green environmental issues. SAGyP is responsible for two semi-autonomous agencies: (a) the National Seed Institute (INASE); and (b) INTA, which has responsibility, inter alia, for forestry research and extension. The proposed project would be implemented by SAGyP and would be limited to plantations, timber processing and agroforestry. 1.25 The 23 Argentinean provinces have different structures of government and administration. In the forest sector, however, while the names of the administrative units differ, the general institutional design is relatively simple. The focal point is a provincial Forestry Directorate (Direccion de Bosques) with responsibility for coordinating the forestry- related activities of all entities, including national, for both native and planted forests. D. Previous Bank Lending 1.26 This is the Bank's first free-standing forestry project in Argentina; earlier, as part of the Agricultural Services and Institutional Development Project, the Bank supported a small sub-component for forestry research (US$1.9 million). E. Lessons from General Bank Experience 1.27 The Bank has lent over US$2 billion for forestry components and free-standing forestry projects. The Forestry Policy Paper of 1978 re- directed Bank financing from an almost exclusive focus on industrial forestry, to a new generation of social, rural development, and environmental forestry projects. Sector work was stressed as the critical link between the policy statement and the lending program. Only one Implementation Completion Report (ICR), and no Project Audit Report (PAR), exists for a forestry project in the Latin America and the Caribbean Region. Lessons learned and other conclusions are derived from Bank studies of sectoral experience. A 1991 OED study of the Bank's forestry experience concludes that the overall performance of this new generation of projects has been satisfactory'. However, consolidation may be a problem given the long maturation period of such projects, especially of their institutional development objectives. Macroeconomic policies and the incentive structure, including the legal and regulatory context, are vital. Government has a key role to play in encouraging the development and use of improved technology in plantation forests. Finally, forestry can have a major impact on alleviating rural poverty in selected locations while also helping to protect native forests. These lessons are also generally corroborated by the 1991 Board paper on Forestry and the 1994 Board paper on forestry project implementation. 1.29 The proposed project represents an appropriate set of public sector interventions aimed at boosting the productivity of plantation forests and timber processing industries while being sensitive to environmental issues in native forest and other ecologically sensitive areas. It heeds lessons from Bank and non-Bank projects that the government has a critical role to play in encouraging and facilitating the use of improved technology in plantation forests, and that forestry and agroforestry can play a key role in alleviating rural poverty in selected locations while also helping to protect native forests. A description of lessons learned and how the project was designed to take into account these lessons is given in Annex A. F. Bank Strategy 1.30 The Bank's country assistance objectives and strategy for dealing with forest plantations, timber processing and agroforestry have been defined through intensive mission contact since the start of 1992, leading to a Forestry Sector Review (Report No. 11833-AR, dated April 26, 1993), and continuing into the identification, preparation and appraisal of the proposed project. The solutions to the issues and problems that confront Argentine forest plantations, timber processing industries and agroforestry are consistent with the Bank's country assistance strategy and its forestry, environmental, and sector policies. Bank support for economy-wide policies and actions necessary, inter alia, for the realization of Argentina's commercial forestry potential is being pursued as part of the country dialogue and economic work program. 1.31 It is proposed that the other policies and actions deemed appropriate be pursued under the proposed Forestry Development Project. The Bank can be of great assistance to the government in helping it to develop and to implement an appropriate state role in support of the development of forest plantations, timber processing industries, and agroforestry.
 - 10 - II. THE PROJECT A. Origin and Concept 2.1 Consistent with the recommendations of the Bank's recently- completed Forestry Sector Review (Report No. 11833-AR, dated April 26, 1993), the Government strategies for developing forest plantations and timber processing industries, fostering agroforestry, and dealing with the prevention of desertification in Patagonia imply a role for the private sector emphasizing the production and marketing of commercial goods and services. There would be a lean role for the state limited mainly to the creation of a supportive policy, legal and regulatory framework, the production of goods and services with a high public good content, and support of agroforestry in selected areas to alleviate rural poverty. Examples of public goods would be: (a) producing public information on the stock of trees in the nation's forest plantations; (b) producing market and price information; (c) developing genetically-improved seed and promoting the production and use of improved seedlings; and (d) producing and disseminating information about improved technical packages for the establishment and management of plantations. The proposed project, which was prepared with assistance from the Government of Japan in the form of a grant, would help the Argentine Government implement the public sector role outlined here. B. Project Objectives 2.2 The objectives of the project would be to contribute to efficient and sustainable growth of forest plantations and timber processing industries, to alleviate rural poverty, and to develop a strategy and consensus for addressing the desertification and soil erosion problems in Patagonia. C. Project Description Project Components 2.3 To achieve these objectives, the project would: (a) create a supportive institutional, policy, legal and regulatory framework; (b) generate and disseminate information which would enable all actors, both public and private, to contribute to narrowing the gap between actual and potential levels of output from forest plantations and timber processing industries; (c) target directly with technical assistance and grants, groups of small farmers in which the incidence of poverty is high, agroforestry can play a central role in improving farming practices, and, as a consequence, alleviate rural poverty and better protect important resources of nearby native forests; and (d) complete a comprehensive study on the Patagonia Region, focussing on the development of an appropriate role for the state to help prevent soil erosion and destruction of natural habitat.
 - 11 - 2.4 The project would have three components: (a) institutional strengthening, including the policy, legal, and regulatory frameworks affecting forest plantations and timber processing industries; (b) research and information generation and dissemination; and (c) support to small farmers in the form of technical assistance and grants in about five areas adjoining important native forests to help them improve their farming practices partly through the use of agroforestry. Institutional Strengthening Component (Baseline Costs US$3.0 million) 2.5 The institutional capacity for dealing with forest plantations and timber processing industries is weak. Based on a comparison between existing institutional capacity and the one implied by the proposed project's development objectives, institutional strengthening would: (a) define a clearer role for the state in forest plantations and timber processing industries in consultation with the private sector; and (b) implement the proposed action program described below to eliminate, or at least mitigate, identified institutional capacity gaps for key capacity elements such as policy-making, legislation/regulations, inter-institutional and internal organization, personnel management, and skills. 2.6 A systematic institutional capacity analysis was carried out and institutional capacity gaps identified against project objectives and tasks. These capacity gaps are addressed in an institutional strengthening component which would: (a) analyze and strengthen the policy, legal, and regulatory frameworks affecting plantations and timber processing industries while ensuring consistency with Argentine environmental laws and regulations; and (b) address identified weaknesses in the principal institutions involved in project implementation: SAGyP's DPF, INASE, and INTA. The baseline cost of the component would be US$3.0 million, and would include expenditures for the acquisition of vehicles, equipment, training, studies, and technical assistance. Further details on this component are given in Annex B. Research and Information Generation and Dissemination Component (Baseline Costs US$13.2 million) 2.7 A research and information generation and dissemination component would support the following actions and investments aimed at generating information with a high public good content concerning commercial forest plantations and timber processing industries: (a) a national inventory of plantations, and establishment and operation of a related database; (b) studies on export markets and development of a grading system for mechanical wood products; (c) the development of a breeding program to achieve a higher level of species domestication; (d) the production and marketing of better seedlings; (e) plantation management research and extension; and (f) strengthening of the information base available (particularly to decision makers in the public sector) for improved management of the
 - 12 - Patagonia region. Further details on this component are given in the following paragraphs and in Annex C. 2.8 Inventory of Forest Plantations and Management of a Related Database (Baseline Costs US$3.0 million). Reliable information on the extent, distribution and condition of forest plantations in Argentina is lacking. Furthermore, with the dissolution of IFONA in 1991, the monitoring of forest product output has ceased and there is now a dearth of up-to-date statistics on production and prices in the sector. A lack of reliable information on the growing stock, the geographical distribution of plantations, tree planting trends, and the annual output of forest products is a constraint to the formation of public policy for the sector. The objectives of the sub-component would be to: (a) complete a plantation forest inventory, and create and maintain current a database on forest plantations; (b) collect, input, and store such other statistics in the database as are necessary for SAGyP to meet its mandate in the commercial forestry sector; and (c) analyze data and disseminate information from the database. 2.9 The first objective would be realized by completing a low intensity, reconnaissance level inventory of plantations, which would collect essential qualitative and quantitative information on the extent, distribution, composition and age structure of forest plantations in Argentina, and inputting the data from the inventory into a database. The second objective would be pursued through strengthened relations between units within SAGyP handling the collection of raw data, but also in cooperation with other agencies, including, in particular, the Instituto Nacional de Estadistica y Censos (INDEC), the provinces, and SRNyAH. 2.10 Phase 1 of the plantation forest inventory would have a baseline cost of US$1.0 million. Given that the tree breeding and selection program is part of a long-term strategy to improve the genetic quality of material available to nurseries, there is still the problem of improving the production, marketing and use of improved seedlings in Argentina. Even if excellent quality genetic material existed domestically, it would only be a source of somewhat superior quality seed over what is available now through importation. Nursery owners would still need to improve their nursery practices to improve the morphological characteristics of seedlings, and plantation owners would still have to overcome their present inability to distinguish between genetically and morphologically superior seedlings and those of lesser quality. A production and marketing research effort to address these latter problems would be the focus of this activity. 2.19 While there is no census of forest tree nurseries for Argentina, it is estimated that there are more than 1,000 operators in the areas covered by the existing government grant program in support of new forest plantation development. Generally, the large nurseries (i.e., 3-7 million seedlings capacity) in Argentina are part of large-scale reforestation operations for pulp mills or large export firms. These large nurseries, which produce about 40 percent of the country's nursery stock to service their own plantations, recognize and have the capacity to use advanced production technology and imported, certified seed. The small to medium-size nurseries, however, which supply more than 60 percent of the country's planting material, and normally sell to smaller producers, generally use genetically inferior seed and outmoded nursery practices, resulting in the production and planting of seedlings of highly variable, and usually poor, quality. With the use of good quality genetic material, along with already

The cold, arid Patagonia region occupies most of the southern part of the country. The region, which covers a total of 762,000 km2 (27 percent of the country), consists of three natural zones, namely: (i) the Steppe, or arid grassland, which is the largest (650,000 km2) and most arid (750 to less than 300 mm precipitation/year); (ii) the Pre-Cordillera, which covers a narrow band of steeply sloping land of altitudes of around 1,000-2,000 MASL, and with annual precipitation of around 750 to 2,000 mm; and (iii) the Cordillera, in the high Andes, with elevations above 2,000 MASL and annual precipitation of 1,000 to 3,000 mm. Strong winds are a characteristic of the entire region. While much of the Cordillera and Pre-Cordillera is well protected in the National Park's system, there are severe desertification problems in the Steppe zone. 2.24 The proximate main cause of land degradation is overgrazing, and grazing during the wrong season, mainly with introduced ruminants. Cattle, sheep and goats have largely replaced the indigenous animals in this region where extensive agriculture (meat, wood, furs and hides) is the main economic activity (US$271 million/annum), accounting for 40 percent of the region's GDP. Pasture management is rare, even on the larger holdings, partially because of the lack of interior and perimeter fencing on both small and large holdings. Overgrazing leads to a general degradation of the native grass ecosystem and a transition to a desert landscape, where unpalatable
 - 17 - shrubs and bare ground begin to dominate. Degraded pastures, dust storms and increased flooding and other symptoms of desertification in the Patagonia have affected the living standards of the local people. Little is known, however, about the overall extent to which desertification has and will affect the ecosystem and the people living in the Patagonia, the underlying forces that drive the process, and the costs to Argentina if the process continues. 2.25 The objectives of this sub-component would be to: (a) collect, analyze, interpret, and report on what is known about the economic, social, biological, historic, climatic and other factors driving the desertification process in Patagonia; (b) determine the costs to Argentina, the local population, and biodiversity and hydrological systems if the process continues unabated; (c) assess the options available for addressing the problem based on research and experience in Argentina, Australia, South Africa, and the United States; (d) estimate the expected cost-benefit ratios of implementing a group of the best options available, both singly and collectively; (e) outline an appropriate role for the state in responding to the phenomenon; and (f) build a consensus among the main stakeholders (federal government, provincial governments concerned, private sector, NGOs) on an action plan consistent with an appropriate role for the state. 2.26 To meet this objective, the project would support a comprehensive study of Patagonia in response to the objectives outlined above. Argentina started to define the role of the State in the forest sector in comprehensive legislation embodied in Law 13273 of 1948. Law 13273 of 1948, encompassed only areas under Federal responsibility ("Territorios Nacionales"). At that time, the government adopted forestry management methods commonly used in European countries. Europe further developed its influence in this sector after World War II, when refugees from many European countries, but most particularly foresters from Croatia, helped Argentine policy makers and its private sector to become aware of the sector's potential and the need for improving production and processing technologies. This coincided with the government's decision to expand its agriculture frontier and become increasingly self sufficient. A Forestry Directorate ("Direcci6n de Bosques") was created in most provinces by provincial governments. Under the influence of European immigrants, the forestry sector started to develop the necessary technology and to boost logging as well as commercial activities. 2. Despite such a promising start, the Provincial Forestry Directorates never had the human resources or the institutional capacity to really enforce Law 13273 of 1948. Provinces did not have skilled professionals to enforce federal or provincial legislation, even when it was effectively created. In other words, the provincial capacity to manage the forest sector was limited by their weak administrative ability to enforce existing laws, to formulate policies, or follow a structured course of action. These constraints contributed to the limited economic development of the forest sector over the years. In addition to the universities that carry forestry programs at the undergraduate and graduate levels, quite a few other entities have been created at the national level to address specific needs. Still others may have a substantial influence on decisions taken at the regional level, although they do not necessarily have an identity strictly related to the forestry sector. In addition to INTA's involvement with research and technology dissemination, there is: (a) INTI, which is involved in the modernization of industrial processes and reports to

In addition, the legislative effort dealing with forestry is coordinated by two ad hoc Forestry Commissions in the House of Representatives and the Senate, respectively. 11. Provincial Institutions. The 23 Argentinean provinces have different organizational arrangements for provincial government and administration. In the forestry sector, however, while the name of the administrative unit may change, the general institutional design is relatively simple. This reflects the organizational setting in all provinces. The focal point is a provincial Forestry Directorate (Direcci6n de Bosques), which is generally located at the third management layer of government, with responsibility for both native and planted forests. Each provincial Forestry Directorate is responsible for coordinating forestry-related activities of all other entities, including national, within its province. These generally include INASE and INTA. 12. The Private Sector. Since an Italian company began the pulp industry in Argentina in the 1920s, the private sector has organized itself into powerful associations and guilds of all sorts. While the private sector has undoubtedly contributed to the development of the forestry sector, it has also been a major obstacle to the full implementation of Law 13273, because of its perception that this law was an impediment to quick and substantial profits. The most important private sector entities are: (a) AFOA, a grouping of all forestry producers; (b) AFCP, which includes the most powerful and wealthy part of the forestry-related private sector; (c) FAIMA, which includes about 2,000 timber companies; and (d) CIEF, a private research entity which conducts research on behalf of its associated members that supplements that carried out by the public sector. Finally, there are many NGOs dealing directly or indirectly with the forest sector and dedicated mostly to raising awareness about the need for protecting natural resources. 13. Institutional Capacity Analysis (ICA) 14. To ensure the design of an institutional development strategy and action plan that would address most pressing priorities, a thorough ICA was carried out at the national and provincial levels, and specific ICGs were identified from the five viewpoints reviewed, namely, rules of the game; interinstitutional relationships; internal organization and management at the entity level; personnel policies and reward systems; and skills of individuals in both the public and private sectors. The analysis has been carried out in an attempt to analyze to what extent the forest sector in Argentina will be able to efficiently achieve the proposed project objectives. A description of the identified ICGs follows. Rules of the Game 15. Within this broad category of institutional capacity, four elements have been identified as limiting the sector's ability to develop, namely, governance, legislation, regulations, and culture. They are analyzed below. 16. Governance. The first element of governance is a clearly articulated and recognizable sectoral role of the State. Unfortunately, no such role is written anywhere, and can only be deduced from Government's decisions and/or informal declarations. Another important element of governance is the transparency and amount of participation allowed in the decision-making process; there is much room for improvement. 17. Poor policies have been the main constraint to the efficient growth of the forest sector in Argentina and to the protection of "green" environmental values. Most of the constraints stemmed from the lack of a clear policy environment outside the sector, including macroeconomic, credit, trade, transportation and labor policies. In recent years, as part of the macroeconomic liberalization and privatization programs of the Government, much has been achieved in eliminating policy distortions affecting the sector. These measures will go a long way toward fostering efficient and sustainable growth in the sector and in removing incentives for depleting the "green" environment. 18. When private sector representatives are interviewed about changes they would like to see in the role of the State, they generally have precise ideas: (a) increased awareness on the part of the Government of the sector's potential; (b) more public sector stimuli (direct promotion and fiscal incentives) to expand production; (c) more openness to the private sector to
 - 44 - Annex B ensure its participation in the decision-making process, in particular on matters relating to international markets; and (d) research and extension programs more in line with private sector priorities and dictated by market conditions. 19. Legislation. Policy constraints to forestry growth and environmental protection still exist, however, mainly contained in sector- specific legislation. National forest policy in Argentina, as stated in Law 13273 of 1948, was very advanced for its time in that it struck a balance between conservation and commercial objectives. The law was less successful in its choice of policy instruments, because it favored "command and control" mechanisms rather than market-based mechanisms, which would have been more appropriate given the dominance of private forests in most of Argentina. Important policy constraints to forest development and environmental protection also remain at the provincial level. Provinces play a critical role in forest policy, but in most cases they have failed to implement the farsighted approach contained in law 13273 of 1948. Furthermore, provincial legislation tends to exacerbate the weakness of law 13273 by relying too much on "command and control" mechanisms that, for the most part, are misdirected and fail to achieve the underlying objectives. For example, some of these measures attenuate property rights by reducing private option values. This creates incentives against forests and in favor of competing uses, and introduces disincentives for conservation and forest development. Also, because provincial sectoral legislation varies widely between regions, it creates inefficiencies in the location of the industry and fosters a provincial bureaucracy that, in many cases, does little more than collect special taxes to finance itself. 20. Non-forest provincial policies also play an important role in distorting sector activities. Some provinces adopted special taxation schemes to promote value-added processing within provincial borders. Other provinces impose a tax on shipments of timber raw materials to outside the province, a practice that may even be unconstitutional. Transportation is still highly regulated at the provincial level, leading to the appearance of trucking associations that behave like oligopolies and increase the transportation costs of timber products. Finally, provincial legislation is particularly poor in the area of "green" environmental protection. Although most environmental values are national or global in scope, and it would not make sense for a province to take most initiatives in the absence of transfer payments from the federal government or the global community, there are still important local values, particularly for quality water supply and soil conservation, that are poorly protected. 21. Regulations. Furthermore, the related regulations are inadequate. For instance, in case of fire, there is no special mechanism to mobilize the population as provided for in the law. Also, there are no professionals to fight forest fires. This may result in the situation being worsened when only volunteer fire fighters, without training or guidance,
 - 45 - Annex B are available. Regulations are also missing to help minimize risks. The existing fine system is obsolete and does not stimulate prudence. In the field of regulations related to commerce and industry, there is also a need for updating or creating new rules of the game, in particular to foster productivity increases and exports. Finally, the regulations related to watershed management are particularly weak. 22. Culture. Finally, it is readily acknowledged in Argentina that there is little or no "forestry culture" as compared with neighboring countries such as Chile. Awareness of both the sectoral development potential and the possibility of expanding the forestry capital stock, instead of just destroying it, is far from being sufficient. The development of such an awareness is seen by the private sector as an important role of the public sector. Another example of weak institutional capacity because of prevailing cultural patterns is given by native populations (Mapuches in particular) who used to invade forests of araucaria and araucana to eat their nutritious fruits, thus, depleting wide areas of valuable trees. Interinstitutional Relationships 23. The network of interinstitutional relationships within the forestry sector is complex and unstable. In addition, most of the relationships are de facto or informal rather than thought through on the basis of the need for many entities to cooperate and interrelate to efficiently implement their work programs. Even when specific mechanisms exist such as CNB, it has no power whatsoever except to give advice. Experience has shown that this advice is rarely taken. At least this is the feeling in the private sector when CNB is mentioned. Internal Organization and Management at the Entity Level 24. Organization at the entity level within the forestry sector is at least as weak as it is at the interinstitutional level. In SRNyAH, weaknesses derive from its recent creation and the lack of overall experience as to how to get organized to respond to the specific needs of the country in protecting the environment and preserving natural resources. In the case of SAGyP's DPF, it is evidently located at too low a level hierarchically to have much influence or prestige. 25. This picture is further aggravated by gaps related to other elements of capacity also included in the broad category of "organization". These gaps are less specific to the forestry sector and more common to many public entities in Argentina. Management procedures and styles often seem antiquated. They do not include participatory mechanisms, except in very rare occasions. The entity-level interpretation of prevailing civil service rules is narrow and many entities' staff "work to rule", slowing down all processes and certainly activating only part of their skills. Only rarely are there adequate and updated manuals at the administrative and technical levels.
 - 46 - Annex B Finally, as in many other sectors, entities are given responsibilities and work programs without the corresponding physical and financial resources (operating budgets) commensurate with the scope of their work. Facilities are not well maintained and run. Office equipment and technology generally do not cover the needs and tend to be obsolete as well. This situation has often been denounced by the private sector when explaining the low credibility level of the public sector. As a result, this element of capacity is far from adequate. On the contrary, any sector modernization effort aimed at achieving higher levels of performance and competitiveness in international markets, while simultaneously renewing the forestry sector's capital stock, both quantitatively and qualitatively, is going to be severely hampered by the above-described situation. Personnel Policies and Reward Systems 26. On this subject there is not much to say that would be specific to the forestry sector. However, this does not make the identified ICGs less severe when trying to achieve sectoral development objectives. It is well- documented that the civil service in Argentina needs to be reorganized in line with other government efforts to modernize the entire administrative machinery. Salary levels in the forestry sector are not at all competitive with the private sector. As a result, the private sector retains the best specialists, which is not necessarily a bad thing in itself. However, as the role of the State in the sector becomes leaner, the need for a competent core of specialists within sector institutions is critical. Current personnel policies do not give any premium for the number of years specialists have spent in the same job and/or specialty. The system is seen as broadly unfair. Many of the existing higher- and mid-level specialists have a second job working in private activities that have nothing to do with the forestry sector. This is particularly serious in a sector in which a high level of competency is necessary to implement reforms such as the ones under the proposed project, including policy-making, definition of strategies to stimulate efficiently the private sector, strategies to expand exports, and to enforce natural resource legislation and regulations. There is an acute need to hire and retain higher- level professionals, but these cannot be attracted by the present levels of compensation. Finally, from the viewpoint of the last institutional capacity category that has been reviewed while preparing the proposed project, namely, skills of people at all levels involved in interinstitutional relationships, wide capacity gaps exist, largely, but not exclusively, explained by the previously-described capacity gaps. Information obtained through informal interviews of both public sector officials and private sector entrepreneurs show that skills are missing at all levels, including in the private sector, to achieve the development tasks implied in the Government priority objectives. The majority of decision-makers are new to the sector.

In the private sector, managers do not have the management or technical skills at the level required by an industry that wants to aggressively penetrate highly competitive international markets. Workers in the industry are generally unskilled, contributing to a well-known wastage of primary products. Finally, the population in general, including the groups visiting national parks or other protected areas, have neither a conservation culture nor awareness of what is expected from them as a contribution to natural resource protection. In other words, the global skill capital of the people, including within the sectoral institutional universe, is deficient. This probably will be a severe impediment to implementing the proposed sectoral development strategy if it is not addressed speedily and adequately. Conclusion 28. The Argentine Forest Sector has a weak institutional capacity because: (a) the sectoral role of the State and related development policy is only vaguely defined and is not sufficiently explicit or transparent; (b) the institutional environment is which the sector is developing is not conducive to the achievement of the highest development potential in terms of preserving natural resources and, at the same time, realizing the sector's full productive potential; and (c) the capacity of the sectoral institutional universe is weak. The minifundio, as a subsistence unit, has an economic rationale that differs substantially from that of larger farms: its goal is to secure the family's food supply and other subsistence requirements by whatever means possible. Some of the main agricultural activities of small farmers by region are: (i) cotton, tobacco, yerba mate, cassava, horticulture and cattle in the NEA region; (ii) sugar cane, tobacco, cotton, sheep, goats and andean camelids in the NOA region; (iii) fruits and goats in the Salta- Jujuy region; (iv) sheep and goat raising in the Patagonia region; and (v) dairy cattle, goats and cereals in the Center region. The production scheme of the minifundio is essentially a subsistence system based on the use of the farmer's own labor and the available natural resources. 7. Because of the tremendous pressure that small farmers place on the natural forest resources, mainly through their farming and grazing practices, Government has recognized the need to assist these people to adopt more sustainable and less environmentally-destructive farming systems. Work being done by agencies such as Fundaci6n INTA, Provincial Ministries, GTZ, Universities and NGOs (such as FUNDAPAZ), has shown that improvement is possible, but only when farmers' interest and needs are properly understood and their limitations adequately considered.

The objective of the small farmer component, therefore, would be: (a) to alleviate rural poverty; and (b) to protect native forest areas, by addressing the two main limiting factors faced by small farners as they attempt to improve their farming practices: (i) availability of technical assistance and information on improved, sustainable technologies; and (ii) access to the funds required to implement the technical packages. The strategy would be to expand successful small farmer-oriented programs which are either demand-driven or that respond to some of the needs of minifundistas. Efforts would be directed at: (a) stabilizing shifting cultivation and reducing overgrazing in fragile forest areas of particular significance to the conservation of natural resources; (b) intensifying and diversifying farming activities in areas where crop production and transhumant pastoralism are threatening fragile areas; (c) developing improved technologies adapted to small farming systems; and (d) increasing small farmer's and especially their children's sensitivity toward environment values, environmental degradation, and the need to conserve natural resources where possible. To be successful, activities would have to expand and sustain the participation of local people and be executed through farmer's groups or associations, so as to facilitate the adoption of technological alternatives that could not be easily integrated by individual farmers. Farmer's groups or associations--formed spontaneously or promoted by Fundaci6n INTA, by other public and private institutions or by NGOs-- would be the main instruments for the implementation of this component. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Forestry Development Project will be to contribute to efficient and sustainable growth of forest plantations and timber processing industries, to alleviate rural poverty, and to develop a strategy and consensus for addressing the desertification and soil erosion problems in Patagonia. To achieve these objectives, the project will: 1) create a supportive institutional, policy, legal regulatory framework; 2) generate and disseminate information which will enable all actors, both public and private, to contribute to narrowing the gap between actual and potential levels of output from forest plantations and timber processing industries; 3) target directly with technical assistance and grants, groups of small farmers in which the incidence of poverty is high, agroforestry can play a central role in improving farming practices, and, as a consequence, alleviate rural poverty and better protect important resources of nearby native forests; and 4) complete a comprehensive study on the Patagonia Region, focusing on the development of an appropriate role of the state to help prevent soil erosion and destruction of natural habitat.
